title: Morrison condemns Turkey over Syria invasion
text:
US President Donald Trump ordered on the weekend the withdrawal of US forces from northern Syria, whose presence had helped protect the Kurdish people, a longstanding US ally, most recently in the fight against Islamic State.

While Mr Trump warned Turkey's hardline President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan against launching an offensive, Turkish forces on Wednesday staged airstrikes and shelled border towns.

Asked whether he agreed with Mr Trump's decision to withdraw troops, Mr Morrison replied it was a sovereign decision for the US.

While Mr Trump has been condemned for abandoning the Kurdish allies, Mr Morrison said he was showing the same respect to the US he would expect other countries would extend to Australia by not commenting on Canberra's decisions on troop deployments.

"It's not for me to run a commentary. They are their troops, they are deployed by the US government, not by Australia or anyone else," Mr Morrison said.

"The US has been doing the lion's share of the lifting when it comes to the effort in the Middle East.

"It's just a simple statement of fact, not a statement of commentary, that this decision is consistent with statements this president has been making for some time."

Mr Morrison said he and Foreign Minister Marise Payne had personally been in contact with overseas counterparts on the issue.

"We will be working through all diplomatic channels, working with our colleagues whether in Europe, or the United States or elsewhere where we have been in partnership in the Middle East for some time to closely monitor these developments, get some clear understanding of the situation on the ground and consider what possible international responses there are to these issues," he said.
description: PM Scott Morrison has condemned Turkey's invasion of northern Syria following a US troop withdrawal as "deeply concerning".
